title: Low rates hurt ex-RBA boss' hedge funds
text:
The high-flying money managers have been wrong-footed by record low interest rates and central bank liquidity dampening market volatility, robbing traders of the arbitrage opportunities they typically thrive on.

Hedge funds as an asset class generally have not performed anywhere near as well. — Aongus O'Gorman, Willis Towers Watson senior investment consultant

Since the 2008-09 global financial crisis, in most years hedge funds have badly trailed the returns of other investment funds focused on equities, bonds, infrastructure and property which have experienced extended bull markets. The HFRI World Index, an international hedge fund benchmark, has posted an annual return of just 2.4 per cent over the last five years.

An adviser to institutional investors about asset allocation, Willis Towers Watson senior investment consultant Aongus O'Gorman, says hedge funds trading shares, currencies, interest rates and other financial assets have struggled largely due to record-low interest rates.

“Hedge funds as an asset class generally have not performed anywhere near as well,” O'Gorman says.

“There is a dampening effect on markets from central bank activities and that creates less breakdowns in relationships between different assets and causes less asset volatility.”

New career

Stevens is not the first top central banker to join the financial markets. His move into part-time hedge fund roles followed former US Federal Reserve chairman Ben Bernanke who became an adviser to bond fund PIMCO and US hedge fund Citadel.

Advertisement

Former RBA governor Ian Macfarlane served on the international advisory board of Goldman Sachs from 2007 to 2017 and was a director of ANZ for 10 years.

Stevens remains on the board of Macquarie Group, Australia’s most successful international financial services company which has enjoyed outstanding profits and a big share price jump in recent years.

Brett Gillespie is well known in financial markets for anticipating monetary policy movements by the RBA and the US Fed.

Ellerston Capital's macro hedge fund, which Stevens officially joined in September 2017 as a part-time adviser, closed in August after failing to make money for investors.

The fund posted a slightly negative return of -0.77 per cent after fees since inception over two years to July 2019, compared with its stated goal of delivering an annualised 5 per cent net return above the RBA cash rate over rolling three-year periods.

The fund was a small component of Ellerston Capital’s $5 billion investment pool overseen by Ashok Jacob, a long-time adviser to billionaire James Packer.

The $200 million Sydney-based fund was run by veteran global interest rate trader Brett Gillespie who previously managed almost $1 billion for global macro powerhouse Tudor Investment in London.

Gillespie is well known in financial markets for anticipating monetary policy movements by the RBA and the US Fed.

Advertisement

Stevens has known Gillespie for years from the RBA’s consultations with financial market participants to keep in touch with economic developments.

Stevens’ part-time role at Ellerston was to advise the fund’s portfolio managers on international markets and central banks, not specifically the RBA.

He was not responsible for making the final investments decisions executed by portfolio managers.

Stevens declined an interview request about his post-RBA career.

The Ellerston fund's strongest investment conviction bet was that US inflation and global interest rates would rise. Stevens in 2017 publicly noted the risks of a sharp rise in inflation that would have "considerable implications" for financial markets.

Started to pay off

The fund's trade started to pay off as US President Donald Trump’s tax cuts, low US unemployment, wage rises and stirring inflation prompted the Fed to raise the funds rate by 1.75 percentage points to a target range of 2.25-2.50 per cent between 2016 and December 2018.

Advertisement

The 10-year US Treasury yield jumped from about 1.5 per cent to 3.25 per cent by October 2018, boosting the fund's returns from short selling US Treasuries.

The fund’s portfolio managers were also talking up that inflationary pressures would catch on in Australia and tipped the RBA would be lifting rates in 2018.

Veteran financier Jon Horton of NWQ Capital Management. Stefan Gosatti

But the interest rate trades ultimately soured when US economic outlook softened, inflation subsided and Fed chair Jerome Powell halted his rate hike cycle and cut interest rates this year.

The RBA was cutting rates by June 2019.

The fund’s chief economist, Tim Toohey, quit to join Yarra Capital. The fund’s back-up portfolio manager Robert Chiu had also departed.

Announcing the closure to investors in an August letter, chief investment officer Chris Hall said: “The Fund has experienced a loss of a key member of the team which has changed the profile of the strategy that was originally offered.”

Investors were delivered their remaining money back.

Advertisement

Stevens had also joined Perth-based NWQ Fiduciary Fund in September 2017 as a member of the investment committee.

NWQ Capital Management, run by veteran financier Jon Horton, had been named Australia’s best hedge fund investor a year earlier by the Alternative Investment Management Association.

Yet over the most recent three years NWQ’s fund has returned 2.9 per cent a year versus 11.9 per cent for the S &P/ASX 200 Accumulation Index, according to its website.

Suffered investor redemptions

Since inception in May 2013, the fund is up 5.52 per cent a year, versus the 8.76 per cent benchmark.

The NWQ fund has also suffered investor redemptions from several wealthy Perth clients and its assets under management have fallen from about $130 million to about $100 million, said market sources familiar with the fund.

Horton was travelling and not available to immediately respond, a colleague said.

NWQ’s performance reflects the wider industry’s struggles because its "fund of fund" business model is to invest in a basket of other hedge funds.

Advertisement

To be sure, it is difficult to generalise too much about hedge funds because their strategies differ markedly, ranging across global macro, long-short equities, credit, algorithmic, commodities and merger arbitrage.

Aongus O'Gorman of Willis Towers Watson ... investors are anxious about lofty asset valuations.

Their purpose is portfolio diversification and protection in times of whip-sawing markets.

The key point hedge fund managers and asset consultants emphasise is ultra-low interest rates have smothered market volatility and hurt their performance.

One experienced hedge fund manager says his analysis shows the volatility of US GDP and inflation have both halved since the financial crisis, as measured quarterly.

Volatility in asset markets also slumped, with central bank bond buying removing “tail risk” in markets.

Meanwhile, Ronan McCabe, Mercer head of portfolio management, says: “Volatility in all markets and asset classes has been quite muted due to QE [quantitative easing], low rates and central bank liquidity, and that’s not a great environment for hedge funds.”

Hedge funds 'have different role'

Advertisement

But it’s wrong to measure the performance of hedge funds against stock market indexes because that’s like comparing “apples and oranges”, he says.

“The hedge funds have a different role in the portfolio and they should really come into their own with outsized returns when equity markets fall like Q4 last year.”

The world’s largest hedge fund, Ray Dalio’s Bridgewater Associates Pure Alpha, rose 14.6 per cent net of fees in 2018, with most of those gains coming late last year as central banks increased rates and the US-China trade war slowed the global economy.

Bridgewater counts the Australian government’s $166 billion Future Fund as a client.

The strong-performing Future Fund had $22.8 billion or 13.7 per cent allocated to “alternative investments” as of September 30, overwhelmingly with offshore money managers.

The local hedge fund market is relatively small by global standards.

It turns out some strategies can be replicated quantitatively or systematically for a much lower fee. — Ronan McCabe, Mercer head of portfolio management

Advertisement

The Future Fund is prepared to pay high fees to a select number of perceived quality global hedge funds for highly tailored strategies, often with sophisticated technology-driven institutions.

But market participants say many local superannuation funds are eschewing the old hedge fund model.

Super funds are reluctant to pay the high “2 and 20” fees historically demanded by hedge funds (2 per cent annual charge on assets under management and 20 per cent share of profits).

Super funds typically allocate only about 5 per cent of their portfolio to hedge funds, with some larger funds prepared to go to a 10-15 per cent limit.

Internationally, more pension funds have followed the lead of California's biggest retirement plan, the $US380 billion CalPERS, which five years ago quit hedge funds due to their complexity and high fees.

Kim Bowater of Frontier Advisors. "We do think they can add value, but it has to be a quite specific strategy and managers."

Alternative Investment Management Association general manager Michael Gallagher says more retail investors are allocating to alternative strategies or hedge funds, with almost 60 per cent of AIMA's local members reporting they have retail products, compared to less than 20 per cent five years ago.

Fees remain under pressure.

Advertisement

The advent of machine learning and computer-driven data analysis means hedge fund-like strategies can now be replicated for a fraction of the cost, such as the emerging "Smart Beta" strategies like factor investing and systematic trend following,

“It turns out some strategies can be replicated quantitatively or systematically for a much lower fee,” Mercer's McCabe says.

Asset consultants advising institutional investors believe there remains a valuable niche role for hedge funds.

Frontier Advisors director of consulting, Kim Bowater, says a small allocation to certain hedge fund strategies is appropriate in a diversified portfolio to complement investments in shares, infrastructure and property.

“We do think they can add value, but it has to be a quite specific strategy and managers,” she says.

As a general rule Frontier prefers to select global macro funds, managed funds that trade futures known as CTAs, alternative risk premiums such as factoring and insurance securities like catastrophe bonds.

Investors anxious

Bowater says Frontier sees less value in paying expensive fees for long-short equity hedge funds that are closely correlated to products offered by cheaper fund managers.

Willis Towers Watson’s O'Gorman says investors are anxious about lofty asset valuations and unsure how they can generate good returns over the coming years.

“Hedge fund strategies that have less economic sensitivity may be of more interest,” he says.

“But then there is the question of fee budgets and conviction.”
description: Two hedge funds that former RBA governor Glenn Stevens joined have struggled, reflecting how ultra-low interest rates have hurt the hedge fund industry.
